title: College Mathematics
description: A brief summary of the mathematics courses I took at the University of Washington Bothell.

sections.content: This is a reflection on my experience with mathematics in college. The following is a list of classes I've taken.

- STMATH 126 - Calculus 3 - Honestly sorta sucked freshman year, but I guess it focused more on series type data.
 - STMATH 300 - Foundations of Modern Math - An introduction proofs class. I wish I took this class, and decided against the double major. Proofs are not really that relevant to programming and are more of a niche theoretical field.
 - STMATH 308 - Matrix Algebra - They skipped linear algebra and went straight for matrix algebra, though great for 3D graphics. I wish I took the proofs class before this though, since I mostly learned it through a less intuitive way and things didn't click untill later.
 - STMATH 381 - Discrete Mathematics - Gotta be honest, this seems like a basic algorithms course. Covered algorithms like Kruskal's, Primm's, Dijkstra's, Markov Chains, and a few other very niche specific algorithms and applying them to irregular data sets. It seems like useful practice for modelling human world applications on computers.
 - STMATH 405 & 406 - Numerical Analysis I & II - This was a difficult class. It focused on a wide variety of topics like floating point error and generating line fitting curves. Seems useful for graphical data plotting applications
 - 409 - Advanced Linear Algebra - Pretty much standard college level linear algebra mixed with heavy amounts of proofs.
 - STMATH 424 - Real Analysis - Don't remember too well, but this was also really difficult. It was about looking at finite, infinite, and other forms of data and sort of doing a deep dive proofs of different subjects within math.
 - STMATH 324 - Multi-variable Calculus - I think this was more about mapping surfaces to formulas and understanding them I guess.
 - STMATH 341 - Statistics - This class was poorly structured and all online. Pretty much just applied a bunch of different statistics methods to different datasets based on analysis of the problem. Not sure I remember what algorithms I used and why.

Math is weird. It's like a useful thing to have and understand, but also not absolutely necessary to understand certain problems. I could make a full stack webpage with only basic addition and subtraction. I can't if I'm integrating low level 3D graphics pipelines or data analysis graphics that are generated with my own code and not using middleware solutions.
It's really a hit or miss for everyone. I only took it for the opportunity to learn linear algebra, so I could get more familiar with matrix operations and 3D graphics.
